title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: manual provides step--step guide download data species example Sepia apama (Giant Cuttlefish) using galah package R. galah package interface Atlas Living Australia (ALA) APIs, allows query download biodiversity data.

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: Ensure R RStudio installed computer. ’ll also need internet connection download data.

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: First, need install galah package haven’t already. can running following command R console:

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: installing package, load R session:

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: can download data, need configure galah package email. email used identify requests ALA servers. Replace "youremail@email.com" email address.

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: can now download data Sepia apama using series galah functions. ’s complete code :
code: sepia <- galah_call() |>   galah_identify("Sepia apama") |>   galah_select(basisOfRecord, recordedBy, recordedByID, eventType, group = c("basic", "event")) |>   atlas_occurrences()

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: galah_call(): Initializes call ALA API. galah_identify("Sepia apama"): Specifies species interest. galah_select(...): Selects specific fields download. case, selecting basisOfRecord, recordedBy, recordedByID, eventType, along groups basic event. atlas_occurrences(): Executes query retrieves occurrence data.

title: Downloading data using the galah package
text: downloaded data, might want save future use. can using save function: save data file named sepia.RDA data-raw directory. can load data future sessions using:

text: following manual, able download save occurrence data Sepia apama using galah package. process can adapted download data species changing species name galah_identify function.

title: Example analyses with the data
text: several data sets data: cuttlefish: occurrences giant cuttlefish tourism: quarterly counts different types tourism, holiday, visiting family, business, weather: daily min max temperature records oz_lga: spatial polygon map Australian local government areas (LGAs) stations: weather station id’s spatial coordinates matching occurrence data

title: How to extract the tourism data
text: dataset exclusively accessible Monash University students staff. However, universities Australia may similar platforms datasets can utilize package. Steps: Go .monash. Select Library section. . Choose Databases. . Pick -Z Databases. . Select Tourism Research Australia online students. . Click Student Databases double click “Domestic Overnight Trips”. Select quarters, click , add rows. . stopover section, find “Stopover state/region/SA2”, click subsection SA2, add rows. . encounter prompt. . Simply click “Ok”. Now ’s time choose columns. Go “Stopover reason” section select “Holiday”, “Visiting friends relatives”, “Business”, reasons, click columns. . final step go Summation options, click “Overnight trips (000) Sum”, top right corner, click “Download table”. .

what: Collection of data on records of wild life sightings, tourism counts and weather from Australia.

text: goal ecotourism provide data use example analyses. data wild life (cuttlefish) occurrences, tourism counts region weather matching locations.

title: Collection of data on records of wild life sightings, tourism counts and weather from Australia.
text: plot occurrences:
code: library(ecotourism) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) data(oz_lga) data(cuttlefish) ggplot(oz_lga) +   geom_sf(colour="white", fill="grey90") +   geom_point(data=cuttlefish, aes(x=lon, y=lat,                                   label=date),              colour="#EA6900", alpha=0.5) +   xlim(c(113.09, 153.38)) +   ylim(c(-43.38, -10.41)) +   theme_map() #> Warning in geom_point(data = cuttlefish, aes(x = lon, y = lat, label = date), : #> Ignoring unknown aesthetics: label #> Warning: Removed 7 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`).
